message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest mastitis, which is often caused by bacterial infection. Needle aspiration can drain the abscess and dicloxacillin can treat the infection. Mammogram is not necessary at this time while incision and drainage are too invasive. Cessation of smoking may be helpful for the patient’s overall health but is not directly related to the management of mastitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest mastitis or breast abscess, which can be caused by an infection from breastfeeding. Needle aspiration and oral dicloxacillin are the most appropriate course of action to clear the infection without interrupting breastfeeding. Mammogram and cessation of smoking are not relevant to the management of the present condition, and incision and drainage is generally reserved for larger abscesses that do not respond to more conservative measures.

While cessation of smoking is always recommended, it is not the next step in management for this patient’s current condition.

Mammogram is not indicated at this time, and incision and drainage would be necessary only if needle aspiration is unsuccessful. Cessation of smoking is advisable but not the best next step in management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and examination suggest a breast abscess. Needle aspiration followed by oral antibiotics is the first-line treatment for breast abscess. Mammogram is not indicated at this time. Incision and drainage may be necessary if the abscess does not resolve with aspiration and antibiotics. Cessation of smoking is important for overall health but is not directly related to the management of the breast abscess.

Treatment includes needle aspiration and antibiotics such as dicloxacillin. Mammogram is not necessary at this time and incision and drainage is not recommended.
